1.learning_goal: AI Basics & Data Skills: In this unit, students will demystify modern AI (symbolic vs statistical, narrow vs general, ML/DL/LLMs and real-world applications), examine AI’s limits and responsibilities, and build practical Python skills to load, inspect, filter, group, and enrich tabular data using Pandas for simple real-world analyses.

chapters.title: How AI Systems Really Work
chapters.learning_goals: Learn what makes a system “intelligent” in practice, how AI evolved from rule-based logic to data-driven methods, and how to tell AI apart from traditional software in real apps.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What Is Artificial Intelligence?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Artificial Intelligence in practical, non-sci-fi terms; Identify what makes a system “intelligent” in practice; Distinguish AI systems from traditional software

lessons.title: A Short History of AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe how early AI systems were built; Explain why early AI relied on rules and logic; Identify what changed when data became central

lessons.title: Rule-Based AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define rule-based (symbolic) AI; Explain how rules are written and applied; Identify strengths and limitations of rule-based systems

lessons.title: Data-Driven AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define data-driven (statistical) AI; Explain how data replaces explicit rules; Describe why data-driven systems scale better

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the AI in Everyday Apps
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify which parts of everyday tools are actually using AI versus traditional software. Output: A completed worksheet where features of common apps are labeled as “AI” or “non-AI” with brief justifications.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Timeline of AI Milestones
lessons.learning_outcomes: Arrange key AI history events in the correct order and connect each to a simple explanation of what changed. Output: A filled-in timeline that places rule-based AI, expert systems, and data-driven breakthroughs in the right chronological order.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Rule-Based or Data-Driven?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish rule-based AI from data-driven AI by classifying short system descriptions and explaining your reasoning. Output: A categorized list of example systems marked as “rule-based” or “data-driven” with one-sentence explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Designing Rules for a Smart Thermostat
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice writing clear IF–THEN rules and recognize the strengths and limits of rule-based control. Output: A small rule set for a “smart” thermostat written in plain language, plus notes on cases where the rules might fail.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: When Data Beats Rules
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain, using concrete scenarios, why data-driven approaches scale better than manually written rules. Output: A short comparison chart that maps several tasks (e.g., spam detection, handwriting recognition) to whether rules or data would be more practical and why.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Modern AI, Clearly Explained
chapters.learning_goals: Build a clear mental model of how today’s AI works by contrasting symbolic vs statistical approaches, narrow vs general AI, and ML, DL, and LLMs, then apply that understanding to real-world products, data, and common AI myths.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Symbolic vs Statistical AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clearly distinguish symbolic AI from statistical AI; Compare how each approach handles complexity; Identify which approach powers most modern AI systems

lessons.title: Narrow AI vs General AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Narrow AI using real-world examples; Define General AI conceptually and explain why it does not exist today; Correct common misconceptions about AI capabilities

lessons.title: ML, DL, and LLMs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs; Explain how these approaches relate to statistical AI; Use correct terminology when describing modern systems

lessons.title: AI in the Real World
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify real-world applications of AI across industries; Describe what type of data these systems rely on; Explain why AI behavior depends on data quality

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Symbolic vs Statistical Sorting Game
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clearly distinguish symbolic AI from statistical AI by matching descriptions, diagrams, and examples to each category. Output: A completed matching table that assigns each mini-scenario to “symbolic,” “statistical,” or “mixed” with a one-line justification.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Narrow vs General AI Scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Correctly classify example systems as Narrow AI and articulate how they differ from hypothetical General AI. Output: A scenario list annotated as “Narrow AI” or “Not AI / General AI idea” with short clarifications.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: ML, DL, and LLMs Concept Map
lessons.learning_outcomes: Differentiate Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs and show how they relate in a simple visual map. Output: A hand-drawn or digital concept map linking ML, DL, and LLMs with arrows and brief definitions at each node.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Name the AI Behind the Product
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify the type of AI approach and data used in real-world applications across different industries. Output: A table of 8–10 products (e.g., Netflix, spam filter, self-driving car) with columns for “AI type,” “data used,” and “why data quality matters.”

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Busting AI Myths
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize and correct common misconceptions about AI capabilities using precise terminology. Output: A two-column sheet where common AI myths are paired with accurate, concise corrections.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Responsible AI and First Data Tools
chapters.learning_goals: Build a grounded understanding of AI’s limits and societal impact while getting hands-on with Python, NumPy, and Pandas to load, inspect, and reason about real-world tabular data.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: AI Limits and Responsibility
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify common limitations of AI systems; Explain why AI systems can fail or behave unexpectedly; Describe, at a high level, why AI impacts society

lessons.title: Python’s Data Toolbox
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain Python’s role in data analysis workflows; Distinguish Python libraries from core Python language features; Identify when to use Pandas versus NumPy

lessons.title: DataFrames and Series
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DataFrame and Series using tabular data examples; Explain how rows and columns map to DataFrame structure; Navigate and inspect basic DataFrame components

lessons.title: Loading Real Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load CSV data into a Pandas DataFrame; Verify that data loaded correctly using inspection methods; Identify basic issues immediately after loading data

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: AI Limits at a Music App
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze limitations and potential failures of an AI music recommendation system and outline responsible design choices. Output: A short written analysis listing at least three concrete limitations, two failure examples, and two responsibility-focused mitigations.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Python Data Toolbox Overview
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify where Python, NumPy, and Pandas fit in a data workflow and choose the right tool for given mini-tasks. Output: A small “tool selection” checklist mapping common data tasks (e.g., matrix math, table cleaning) to Python core, NumPy, or Pandas.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe Sales DataFrame and Series
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice creating simple Pandas Series and DataFrames to represent a cafe’s daily orders and inspect their structure. Output: A Python script that builds a small DataFrame of cafe orders and prints its shape, columns, and a few Series slices.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Loading Movie Ratings Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load a CSV file into a Pandas DataFrame and verify its structure using basic inspection methods. Output: A Python script that reads a `movie_ratings.csv` file, prints `head()`, `info()`, and `describe()` to the console.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: First Look at Real Survey Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load a real or sample survey CSV, inspect it for obvious issues, and note questions about its contents. Output: A Python script that loads `survey_responses.csv`, displays sample rows and summary info, and prints a short text report of initial observations.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Working with DataFrames
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to read, select, filter, group, and enrich tabular data using pandas, then apply these skills to build simple, real-world reports from raw CSV files.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Reading Data Carefully
lessons.learning_outcomes: Inspect datasets to understand structure and content; Identify potential data issues by scanning rows and columns; Formulate simple questions about what the data represents

lessons.title: Selecting and Filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Select specific columns from a DataFrame intentionally; Filter rows using logical conditions; Explain filtering logic clearly in plain language

lessons.title: Grouping Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group data by categorical features using Pandas; Apply basic aggregations such as mean and count; Interpret grouped results in terms of real-world meaning

lessons.title: Derived Columns
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create new columns derived from existing data; Explain why derived columns can make data more useful; Verify correctness of newly created columns

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Reading Bike Rental Data Carefully
lessons.learning_outcomes: Inspect a bike rental dataset to understand its columns, units, and potential data issues. Output: A Python script that loads `bike_rentals.csv`, prints structural info and sample rows, and writes a short summary of what each key column represents.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Selecting and Filtering Movie Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Select relevant columns and filter rows from a movies DataFrame using clear logical conditions. Output: A Python script that loads `movies.csv`, selects a subset of columns, and prints only movies that meet chosen rating and year criteria.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Grouping Cafe Orders
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group cafe order data by product and compute basic aggregations like total quantity and average price. Output: A Python script that groups a cafe orders DataFrame by item name and prints a summary table with count and mean price per item.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Derived Columns for Sales Insights
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create meaningful derived columns from raw sales data and verify that their values are correct. Output: A Python script that adds columns such as `total_price` and `discounted_price` to a sales DataFrame and prints before/after samples to validate them.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Daily Revenue Report – Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine careful reading, selecting, and filtering to prepare a clean subset of transaction data for analysis. Output: A Python script that loads `store_transactions.csv`, inspects it, selects needed columns, filters out invalid rows, and prints a cleaned preview.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Daily Revenue Report – Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping and derived columns to calculate daily revenue and basic KPIs from the cleaned transaction data. Output: A Python script that groups cleaned transactions by date, computes total revenue and average order value per day, and prints a concise daily report.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

2.learning_goal: Foundations of EDA: In this unit, students will clean and prepare tabular data (fixing types, inspecting outliers, filtering, and grouping), then use exploratory data analysis tools—plots, distributions, variability, and correlation thinking—to ask and answer focused questions about patterns and relationships without over-claiming conclusions.

chapters.title: Cleaning Data for Real Insights
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to fix data types, investigate outliers, apply purposeful filters, and use grouping so you can build a simple, end‑to‑end data cleaning pipeline that produces trustworthy, interpretable analysis.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Fixing Data Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Detect columns with incorrect data types; Convert data types to enable proper analysis; Explain why correct data types are essential

lessons.title: Detecting and Understanding Outliers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify outliers using simple numerical and visual methods; Distinguish between meaningful outliers and problematic outliers; Explain why outliers should be investigated, not automatically removed

lessons.title: Filtering with Purpose
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply filters based on meaningful conditions; Explain why specific filters are applied; Validate that filtering produced expected results

lessons.title: Grouping for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping to compare categories in data; Interpret aggregated values meaningfully; Identify patterns revealed through grouping

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe sales cleanup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Detect and fix incorrect data types in a small cafe sales dataset, explaining why each conversion is needed. Output: A cleaned DataFrame where dates, prices, and quantities have correct types ready for analysis.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings outliers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify and visualize outliers in a movie ratings dataset and decide which are meaningful versus problematic. Output: A summary report (printed or markdown-style) highlighting detected outliers with plots and short justifications.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker filters
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply purposeful filters on a fitness tracker dataset to isolate meaningful subsets and verify the results. Output: Filtered DataFrames and printed checks that confirm the filters match the intended conditions (e.g., steps over a threshold, specific days).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store grouping
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping and aggregation on an online store orders dataset to compare categories and interpret the patterns. Output: Grouped tables (e.g., revenue by category or weekday) and brief printed interpretations of key insights.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Data cleaning mini pipeline
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine type fixing, outlier inspection, filtering, and grouping into a mini cleaning-and-insight pipeline on a mixed dataset. Output: A processed dataset plus a short printed summary of main findings after each step (types fixed, outliers flagged, filtered subset, grouped insights).

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Exploratory Data Analysis in Action
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to explore raw data with the right plots, summaries, and questions so you can spot patterns, anomalies, and data types without jumping to conclusions or full modeling.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What EDA Really Means
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define exploratory data analysis in clear, practical terms; Explain the goals of EDA before modeling or decisions; Distinguish EDA from final conclusions

lessons.title: First Plots for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create basic plots using matplotlib; Choose plot types appropriate to specific questions; Interpret plots to describe trends and patterns

lessons.title: Patterns and Anomalies
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify patterns emerging from data exploration; Detect anomalies and unusual values; Explain findings clearly without over-interpreting

lessons.title: Data Types & “What am I analyzing?”
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish numerical vs categorical variables; Identify whether a question is univariate or relationship-based; Understand that choosing appropriate summary statistics and visualizations is based on data type and know the main techniques according to data type

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: EDA concepts check
lessons.learning_outcomes: Differentiate between EDA, modeling, and final conclusions through matching, short-answer, and scenario questions. Output: Written answers identifying which activities are EDA, which are conclusions, and explanations of EDA goals.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app first plots
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create basic matplotlib plots (histogram, bar chart, line plot) on a music app listening dataset and explain which questions each plot answers. Output: A set of plots with short text descriptions interpreting key trends and patterns.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Patterns and anomalies in deliveries
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explore a delivery times dataset to spot patterns and anomalies, documenting observations without over-claiming. Output: Simple visualizations and a concise narrative describing typical behavior and unusual cases.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Data types and questions quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Classify variables as numerical or categorical and label questions as univariate or relationship-based, choosing appropriate summaries and plots. Output: A completed worksheet-style answer set mapping each question to variable types, summary statistics, and visualization choices.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Mini EDA on bookstore data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Perform a focused EDA on a small bookstore sales dataset, from first plots to pattern/anomaly notes, staying within the boundaries of exploration. Output: A short EDA notebook or script with plots and bullet-point observations that clearly separate description from conclusions.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Seeing Data Distributions Clearly
chapters.learning_goals: Build intuitive skills for reading distributions, choosing between mean and median, and understanding variability and randomness so you don’t get misled by single-number summaries or noisy patterns.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Distributions - Looking beyond single numbers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain what a distribution represents; Interpret basic distribution shape using a histogram or bar chart; Describe why summary statistics alone can be misleading without distribution context

lessons.title: Mean vs Median - Choosing the right “average”
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define mean and median with practical examples; Select mean vs median depending on skew and outliers; Explain how outliers can distort the mean and affect interpretation

lessons.title: Variability & Standard Deviation (Intuition)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain variability as how spread out values are; Interpret standard deviation at an intuitive level; Compare two datasets and infer which has more variability

lessons.title: Randomness, Noise & Why patterns can be misleading
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define randomness and noise in real datasets; Recognize when a pattern may be caused by noise rather than signal; Explain why repeated measurements or samples may lead to different results

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Distributions intuition
lessons.learning_outcomes: Interpret histograms and bar charts of different datasets to describe distribution shape and why single-number summaries can mislead. Output: Written explanations comparing pairs of distributions and highlighting what the shape reveals beyond the mean.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Ride-sharing fares distribution
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze the distribution of ride-sharing fares with histograms and describe skew, typical ranges, and potential issues with relying only on averages. Output: Plots plus a short textual summary explaining the fare distribution and implications for using the mean.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Mean vs median in housing prices
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compute and compare mean and median for simulated housing price data with and without extreme values, deciding which measure is more appropriate. Output: Printed statistics and a short interpretation showing how outliers change the mean and affect conclusions.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Variability in game scores
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare variability and intuitive standard deviation in score distributions for two mobile games, identifying which is more consistent. Output: Side-by-side plots and a brief explanation of which game has more spread and what that means for players.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Randomness and noisy patterns
lessons.learning_outcomes: Simulate random data with noise, visualize apparent patterns, and explain which patterns are likely due to chance. Output: Plots of noisy data and a short commentary distinguishing real structure from randomness and why repeated samples differ.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking in Relationships
chapters.learning_goals: Build intuition for how two or more variables relate, including when and how to use bivariate and simple multivariate analysis. Learn to interpret correlation (Pearson vs Spearman) carefully, avoid “correlation = causation” traps, and choose appropriate visualizations to explore these relationships.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Bivariate Thinking - Relationships between two variables
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify when a question requires bivariate analysis; Choose an appropriate visualization for different variable type combinations; Describe what it means for two variables to move together at an intuitive level

lessons.title: Correlation - Pearson vs Spearman (High level)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define correlation and interpret positive vs negative correlation; Differentiate Pearson (linear) vs Spearman (rank or monotonic) at a high level; Explain when Spearman may be more appropriate than Pearson

lessons.title: Correlation ≠ Causation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why correlation does not imply causation; Identify common pitfalls such as confounders and reverse causality; Propose ways to reduce wrong conclusions using additional variables or domain reasoning

lessons.title: Multivariate Intuition - When relationships change
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why adding a third variable can change an observed relationship; Describe controlling for another variable conceptually; Understand how multivariate thinking connects to feature selection and ML modeling decisions at a high level

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Bivariate thinking scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Decide which questions require bivariate analysis and select appropriate visualization types for different variable combinations. Output: A written set of answers matching each scenario to “univariate vs bivariate” and a recommended plot type.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Study hours and exam scores
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explore the relationship between study hours and exam scores using scatter plots and describe how the two variables move together. Output: A scatter plot with a brief interpretation of the apparent relationship and its strength/direction.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Correlation types quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Interpret correlation examples and distinguish when Pearson vs Spearman correlation is more appropriate at a high level. Output: Answered questions that label each scenario with correlation direction/strength and the preferred correlation type with justification.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Correlation not causation stories
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze short story-based examples of correlated variables to identify possible confounders, reverse causality, and safer interpretations. Output: Written explanations for each story that separate correlation from causation and propose better reasoning or additional data needed.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Multivariate restaurant ratings
lessons.learning_outcomes: Examine how adding a third variable (e.g., price range) changes the observed relationship between restaurant rating and delivery time, building multivariate intuition. Output: Plots or grouped summaries by the third variable and a concise explanation of how the relationship shifts when controlling for it.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges
